sentence: 1. I used to work for Goodyear, but I had to quit... I got too tired.

explanation: tired can mean both exhausted and refers to a type of rubber (tire)
first_new_sentence: After a long day of hiking, I felt extremely tired.
second_new_sentence: The car needs a new set of tired for better performance.

sentence: 2. What do you call an aging actor who has finally paid off his house? mortgage freeman.

explanation: mortgage refers to a loan specifically for real estate and can also mean to confer a lien on property
first_new_sentence: They took out a mortgage to buy their first home.
second_new_sentence: After years of financial strain, they finally felt the weight of their mortgage lifted.

sentence: 3. What do you call a deer with no eyes? I have no-eye-deer.

explanation: idea can mean a thought or plan and is cleverly related to the phrase I have no idea.
first_new_sentence: She had a brilliant idea for the project.
second_new_sentence: His latest idea was so abstract that no one could decipher it.

sentence: 4. What do they call me in prison? mitochondria, cause Im the powerhouse of the cell.

explanation: power can mean physical strength or energy and can also refer to control or authority
first_new_sentence: The athlete demonstrated incredible power during the competition.
second_new_sentence: The government has the power to enforce the law.

sentence: 5. What do you get when you throw a bomb in a French bathroom? linoleum blown-apart.

explanation: blown can refer to the action of a wind impact and also to an explosion
first_new_sentence: The leaves were blown across the yard by the strong wind.
second_new_sentence: His chances of winning the contest were blown after he failed to submit his entry on time.

sentence: Please note that while tired to tire and blown to blow fits the criteria, they may slightly stretch beyond the easy understanding of single meanings within humor.
